Comments_List: I learned a lot that one would learn in the first semester of Calculus A.B., primarily single variable differentiation.
How to take a derivative
understand conceptual pieces of math better
relearned calculus in a more in depth way than J did in high school
I learned more about Calculus
I gathered a better understanding of the first half of calculus and benefitted from reviewing the aspects needed to learn calculus.
I learned how to think critically about math
More thorough notes on board in classes that will help with psets, exams questions

Strengths: I really liked the book chosen; it really helped refresh my precalculus knowledge and made Calculus less daunting. The questions asked on exams were mainly fair, but the grading for partial credit wasnt always fair.

Weaknesses: The weekly workshops. They honestly did nothing for my learning, and I think a discussion section would be more beneficial, in which students go over homework problems with a learning assistant and/or professor. The problem sets due on Tuesdays were also too long. Granted, we had the whole weekend to do them, but many of us have many other problem sets and other work to do.
Better teachers
Teaching was lesser in the section taught by the Graduate Student than Professor Halls section.
The strength is taking the material slow. I did not feel Gabriel was a great instructor so it could be improved by having a better professor.

Strengths: included a lot of information in a short period of time
Weaknesses: I did not enjoy how the course was taught. I thought their methods were not effective.
More focus on material that the homework covered. Going over homework in class
The strength of his course was its cut and dry nature, but the weakness was how difficult the problem sets were. I feel like most werent doable without assistance.

Strengths are the pace and in depth understanding of topics.
Weaknesses are the more theoretical approach to math versus the traditional solving of problems as the hour and a half long sections.

The strengths of this course is the student to teacher ratio and how often the students can meet for office hours and meet TAs. I feel like there could have been more review sessions for midterms and finals in order to better prepare students for the exams.
Self-instruction was prominent and important but helped me learn the material. I would, however, like to see instruction in class reflect what is on Psets and tests.
Yes, the workload was very bearable.
No
Yes
Yes I would. Especially for a student where math is not their strongest subject, this is the class for them.
Only if they need to take math
I.T is helpful if you havent seen calculus before and need to take a math at a slower pace
I would only recommend if they have Prof. John Hall as a teacher.

Yes I would recommend this course. The professors are very passionate and knowledgeable and relay ideas very well. Overall it was a very good environment and experience that I would recommend to anyone deciding to take a math course at Yale.
Yes, it's a good way to establish a foundation in calculus
